greenmirror

Class Relation

  • java.lang.Object
    • greenmirror.Relation
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable

    public class Relation
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable
    A class to model relations between Nodes.

    Relations are always directional: going from node A to node B. Although a name is not required, it is recommended to always specify one.

    Author:
    Karim El Assal

    • Method Detail

      • getId

        public @NonNull java.lang.String getId()
        Returns an id that is as unique as it can get on the basis of the current properties. It is of the format "nodeAid|relationName|nodeBid|placementString|isRigid" where "nodeAid" and "nodeBid" are empty string when they are null. "isRigid" will be replaced by "true" or "false" accordingly.
        Returns:
        a (sort of) unique id

      • getNodeA

        public Node getNodeA()
        Returns:
        node A

      • getNodeB

        public Node getNodeB()
        Returns:
        node B

      • getOtherNode

        public Node getOtherNode(@NonNull Node firstNode)
        Returns the node on the other side of this relation than firstNode is.
        Parameters:
        firstNode - the node you DON'T want
        Returns:
        the node connected to firstNode due to this Relation; null if firstNode is not part of this Relation or if the other node is null

      • getName

        public java.lang.String getName()
        Returns:
        the name of this relation: null if it is not set

      • isRigid

        public boolean isRigid()
        Returns:
        true if this is a rigid relation: if node A moves when node B moves

      • getPlacement

        public @NonNull Placement getPlacement()
        Returns:
        the Placement of node A relative to node b

      • getTemporaryFxOfNodeA

        public FxWrapper getTemporaryFxOfNodeA()
        Returns:
        the FX of node A for the duration of this Relation

      • toString

        public @NonNull java.lang.String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a textual description of this Relation containing all properties

      • setNodeA

        public @NonNull Relation setNodeA(Node node)
        Sets the starting node of this directional relation.
        Parameters:
        node - the node that will be set as node A
        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if node A is being set while a temporary FX is set, but node A doesn't have its own FX (and node is not null)

      • setNextNodeA

        public @NonNull Relation setNextNodeA(@NonNull NodeList nodes)
        Sets node A to the next node in the list of nodes. If the end of the list is reached, the first is selected.
        Parameters:
        nodes - the nodes to choose from
        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if no node could be chosen from the list

      • setNodeB

        public @NonNull Relation setNodeB(Node node)
        Parameters:
        node - the node that will be set as node B
        Returns:
        this

      • setNextNodeB

        public @NonNull Relation setNextNodeB(@NonNull NodeList nodes)
        Sets node B to the next node in the nodes list. If the end of the list is reached, the first is selected.
        Parameters:
        nodes - the nodes to choose from
        Returns:
        this

      • setName

        public @NonNull Relation setName(java.lang.String name)
        Parameters:
        name - the name to set
        Returns:
        this

      • setRigid

        public @NonNull Relation setRigid(boolean rigid)
        Parameters:
        rigid - whether node A moves when node B moves
        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if this relation is set to be rigid before a placement is set

      • setPlacement

        public @NonNull Relation setPlacement(@NonNull Placement placement)
        sets the placement of node A on node B. It assumes node B has a placement.
        Parameters:
        placement - the Placement of node A relative to node B
        Returns:
        this

      • setNextPlacement

        public @NonNull Relation setNextPlacement(Placement... placements)
        Sets the placement to the next in the list of placements. If the end of the list is reached, the first one is chosen. If the current placement doesn't appear in placements, nothing happens.
        Parameters:
        placements - the list of available placements
        Returns:
        this

      • setTemporaryFxOfNodeA

        public @NonNull Relation setTemporaryFxOfNodeA(@NonNull FxWrapper fx)
        Sets the temporary FX of node A. Node A should already have an FX set.
        Parameters:
        fx - the FX of node A for the duration of this Relation
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if node A doesn't have an FX set

      • fromRelation

        public @NonNull Relation fromRelation(@NonNull Relation originalRelation)
        Applies all properties of originalRelation. This works as a reverse clone().
        Parameters:
        originalRelation - the original relation
        Returns:
        this

      • clone

        public @NonNull Relation clone()
        Overrides:
        clone in class java.lang.Object

      • addToNodes

        public void addToNodes()
        Adds this relation to node A and B's list of Relations. Nodes A and B have to be set.

      • removeFromNodes

        public void removeFromNodes()
        Removes this Relation from the connected nodes' RelationLists.

      • passToNextNodeA

        public @NonNull Relation passToNextNodeA(@NonNull NodeList nodes)
        Removes this relation from the current node A and passes it on to the next one in the list. If nodes doesn't contain the current node A and/or has a size smaller than two, nothing happens.
        Parameters:
        nodes - the list containing the current node A and the next
        Returns:
        this

      • passToNextNodeB

        public @NonNull Relation passToNextNodeB(@NonNull NodeList nodes)
        Does exactly the same as passToNextNodeA(NodeList), but with node B.
        See Also:
        passToNextNodeA(NodeList)
